p.c: Using effectively requires an understanding of its underlying numerics platform, called

simplifies the complexities involved when doing math with amounts that may involve disparate commodities, such as dollars and shares of common stock. For example, assume you have two amounts, one is 100 dollars in an “account”, and the other is 200 Deutsche Mark that you wish to add to that account. What is the result of such an addition? Many accounting systems on the market today do not allow for the accumulation of multiple currency types in a single account, perhaps owing to the complexities of the math involved. But with
, such expressions are not only straightforward, but handled with grace. Let’s setup this calculation in the Common Lisp
, and see what the outcome is. First we must load and initialize
, which is easily done using the
package management system. The following commands assume the use of
; see the Appendices for specific commands appropriate to your implementation.
Now we can create the two amounts involved:
Once created, the function cambl:add can be used to add the two amounts and return a third value representing the addition:
As you can see, the value resulting from this addition is of type cambl:balance, which represents a union of amounts with differing commodities.

variables.variable: An accounting system for Common Lisp users

document-info.comments: CL-Ledger is an accounting system for Common Lisp users.
